name: correct interpolation of random
author: FabriceNeyret2
description:
when interpolating stochastic fields (texture, rand...) at least renormalize stats (right) or you'll got loose and fluctuating contrast (left).
You may even renormalize histograms as in https://hal.inria.fr/hal-01824773 (cf slides), but more complicated.

name: Bandlimited Synthesis 2b
author: FabriceNeyret2
description:
around iq's "Bandlimited Synthesis 2" [url]https://shadertoy.com/view/wtXfRH[/url]
- left: exact box filter  right:  spline filter ( pseudoGaussian )
- top: using fwidth      bottom : using L2 gradient.    blue = isovalue
- click: see 2PI band instead PI
image_code:
// variant of "Bandlimited Synthesis 2" by iq. https://shadertoy.com/view/wtXfRH

#define fwidth2(x) length(vec2(dFdx(x),dFdy(x)))

void mainImage(out vec4 O,  vec2 U )
{
	vec2  R = iResolution.xy, p = 2.*U-R;
    float a = 400.* ( atan(p.y,p.x) + .05*iTime ),               // rays pattern
          f = iMouse.z > 0. ? 1. : .5,                           // click = 2PI band instead of PI
          w = p.y>0. ? fwidth(a): fwidth2(a),                    // L1 or L2 gradient
          v = p.x<0. ?  cos(a)* sin(.5*w)/(.5*w)                 // box filter
                      : cos(a)* smoothstep(f*6.28,0.,w);         // spline filter ( ~gauss )
 
    O = vec4( pow( .5+.5*v , 1./2.2 ) );                         // display ( to sRGB )
    
    O = mix(O, vec4(0,0,1,0), smoothstep(.03,0.,abs(w-3.14) ) ); // isovalue
    R = U-.5 - floor(R/2.); if (R.x*R.y==0.) O = vec4(1,0,0,0);  // red separators
}

name: test2: exact floats ( with mod )
author: FabriceNeyret2
description:
left:   mod(int, int ) is not always 0  ( lines ).
middle:  mod(int + 1/pow2 , int ) is always exact ( plain white ). so mod( fragCoords, int ) is ok, good ! 
right:   otherwise it is always not exact (plain black ).

name: test: exact floats
author: FabriceNeyret2
description:
integers and their divisions by power of 2 can be stored exactly in floats.
But division often breaks this, and thus mod as well ( in particular, 3./3. is not exactly 1 ).
If you see a grid of dots, you have exact (1.+z)/(64.+z) and mod(U,3).
Tell me !

name: Peripheral Drift Inverse
author: copperbotte
description:
I was curious if the observed speed of the Peripheral Drift illusion, (the Rotating Snakes illusion) can be canceled out by a very slight drift. 
For me, it appears to move at ~0.002.5 rads/sec.

Tunable parameters can be found at line 94.

uvec4(0xaaaaaaaa,0xaaaaaaaa,0xaaaaaaaa,0xaaaaaaaa),
uvec4(0xaaaaaaaa,0x0,0x0,0x0));

void mainImage( out vec4 fragColor, in vec2 fragCoord )
{
    fragColor = vec4(0,0,0,1);
    vec2 dim = vec2(240,303);
    // Normalized pixel coordinates (from 0 to 1)
    vec2 uv = fragCoord;
    uv = floor(uv);
    if (uv.x >= dim.x || uv.y >= dim.y) return;
    int index = int(uv.y)*240+int(uv.x);
    uvec4 d = data[index/(16*4)];
    index %= 16*4;
    uint t = d[index/16];
    index %= 16;
    t >>= 2*index;
    t &= 3u;

    // Time varying pixel color
    vec3 col = vec3(float(t)/3.0);//0.5 + 0.5*cos(iTime+uv.xyx+vec3(0,2,4));

    // Output to screen
    fragColor = vec4(col,1.0);
}
